findings.description: Refund allows keeping/transferring tokens (free tokens + ETH refund)
findings.vulnerability_type_claimed: Refund allows keeping/transferring tokens (free tokens + ETH refund)
findings.reasoning: This finding identifies a real, exploitable vulnerability not in the ground truth. The refund logic in refundTRA() fails to burn or reclaim tokens when issuing ETH refunds, allowing users to transfer tokens away before refunding and keep both the tokens and the ETH. This can drain the contract's ETH reserves. The attack scenario is concrete and profitable, requiring no trusted roles.

findings.description: ERC20 approval race condition (double-spend allowance via front-running)
findings.vulnerability_type_claimed: ERC20 approval race condition (double-spend allowance via front-running)
findings.reasoning: This finding identifies a real, well-known ERC20 vulnerability not in the ground truth. The approve function in daoPOLSKAtokens overwrites existing allowances without requiring a reset to zero, enabling a front-running attack where a spender can use both the old and new allowance values. The attack scenario is concrete and profitable, requiring no trusted roles.

findings.description: Public finalize() can be called repeatedly to toggle refund state (griefing / refund DoS)
findings.vulnerability_type_claimed: Public finalize() can be called repeatedly to toggle refund state (griefing / refund DoS)
findings.reasoning: This finding identifies a real vulnerability not in the ground truth. The finalize function is publicly callable after a time condition and uses a toggle for refundstate without any one-time guard or access control. This allows an attacker to repeatedly flip the refund state, causing denial-of-service for legitimate refunders. The attack is concrete and exploitable without privileged access.

target_assessment.type_match_reasoning: None of the three findings mention or describe an unchecked return value vulnerability in PartialFundsTransfer. The ground truth vulnerability is completely absent from the LLM's output.

notes: The LLM failed to identify the target vulnerability (unchecked return value in PartialFundsTransfer) but did identify three other real, exploitable vulnerabilities in the contract. All three findings are valid bonus vulnerabilities. The target vulnerability appears to be a medium-severity issue that the LLM missed entirely.
